Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my dashboard as I pulled up to the curb, my passenger sliding into the back seat with a relaxed smile. He mentioned he was in no rush, just heading to a casual meeting. As a taxi driver, I felt relief—no pressure to speed, just a simple ride. But my mind kept drifting to the office function scheduled for this afternoon. It was a big event, and all my colleagues would be there, men and women mingling freely. 

As a Muslim, I always tried to dress modestly, long sleeves and loose clothing, even in the summer heat. But I knew the office culture leaned toward more casual, even trendy attire. I could already imagine the curious glances, the subtle questions about my choice of dress. Part of me wanted to blend in, to avoid standing out, but another part of me felt the weight of my faith, the importance of holding onto my values. 

Driving through the city streets, I felt the tension building inside me, torn between the comfort of fitting in and the conviction of staying true to myself. The closer I got to my passenger’s destination, the more the question pressed on me: what would I wear this afternoon?
